item.title: Russian New Year (Новый год) and the First Encounter
item.description: Begin = continuation Linked to New Year is a Russian saying (in the realm of superstition) that can sound both motivating and ominous. Как встретишь Новый год (How you begin/meet the New Year), так его и проведёшь (is how it will go).

item.title: Tongue Twisters (2/2): Tricky Sentences and Speed Tests
item.description: Twisting Words The tongue twister in Russian is called скороговоркa (plural скороговорки) and in English, a tongue-twister. For the first part, we dealt with big words (see shibboleth), but with tricky sentences, we’re getting closer to potential accidents. 5 Short Ones The first five from Top 5 Russian Tongue Twisters (Russian with Katya, 2020, 5 m).

item.title: Making Sentences
item.description: Word Order Cats eat mice can also be expressed in Russian as mice eat cats. There’s a lot of freedom in word order. The price for that freedom is declensions and cases. They keep sentences simple but constantly change the words.

item.title: Vocabulary
item.description: With love – here are clips (and resources) to help you learn Russian words and build your vocabulary. Reading First Words Short words that are easy to follow, with pictures included. Да, нет, кот (yes, no, cat): if this is too simple, here is part 2.
